I am sure that you guys spent a lot of time debating this point back in the day, but I would like to point out that this is one of the hidden drawbacks of not providing your own graphical test runner. With your own test runner, users could evaluate new features quickly and easily and then apply pressure to their IDE's to provide support, thus expanding your user base.

Also, it does help those of us who prefer Emacs over Eclipse feel a little less left out in the cold :-).

Rocco

Subject: Re: [junit] Categories in JUnit 4.8

Malte,

Thank you for the question. We went back and forth on this. The two positive features of using interfaces as "tags" is that the compiler can check them and inheritance works. The need for otherwise useless interfaces is the cost of this decision.

To my way of thinking, categories should be handled by the IDE--they are meta-data that belongs with the test runner, not with the tests themselves. Since IDEs don't provide a good solution to running subsets of tests, we can add some value by *an* implementation.

That said, we are open to changing to strings if experience shows that the interface-based categories don't work in practice.

Regards,

Kent
